author: Por Zachary Stieber
title: Reactivan demanda contra moratoria de desalojos de los CDC
text: Una corte federal de apelaciones reactivó una demanda contra la moratoria de desalojo de un mes de duración impuesta por los Centros para el Control y la Prevención de Enfermedades (CDC) de EE.UU., dictaminando que una corte inferior había desestimado erróneamente el caso. El 7 de agosto, la Corte de Apelaciones del Circuito Federal de EE.UU. [declaró](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25035639-ruling-for-owners-in-cdc-eviction-case) que los propietarios que impugnaban la moratoria, que en un principio se presentó como temporal pero que finalmente se mantuvo durante casi un año, argumentaban adecuadamente que la moratoria de los CDC equivalía a una confiscación física de sus propiedades de alquiler. Una parte de la Quinta Enmienda de la Constitución de EE.UU., conocida como cláusula de expropiación, establece que “no se expropiará propiedad privada para uso público sin una compensación justa”. “La orden de los CDC constituye una toma compensable de la propiedad y los derechos de propiedad de los Demandantes sin una compensación justa”, dijeron los propietarios en su demanda. El juez de distrito, Armando O. Bonilla, desestimó el [caso](https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/60090159/darby-development-company-inc-v-united-states/?filed_after=&filed_before=&entry_gte=&entry_lte=&order_by=asc) en 2022, al considerar que las impugnaciones en virtud de la cláusula de la enmienda no podían presentarse a menos que la acción gubernamental impugnada estuviera autorizada por el Congreso. “Los CDC carecían de la autoridad requerida por el Congreso para dictar la moratoria nacional de desalojos residenciales que constituye el núcleo de este caso”, declaró Bonilla. La corte de apelaciones, sin embargo, dijo que los CDC “estaban actuando dentro del ámbito normal de sus funciones” cuando emitió la moratoria, que detuvo los desalojos desde el 4 de septiembre de 2020 hasta mediados de 2021. Una ley federal, por ejemplo, confiere a los CDC y a su director la facultad de “establecer y hacer cumplir los reglamentos que, a su juicio, sean necesarios para prevenir la introducción, transmisión o propagación de enfermedades transmisibles… de un estado o posesión a cualquier otro estado o posesión”, y los CDC citaron esa ley, la Ley de Servicios de Salud Pública (PHSA), en su orden. “En conjunto, las circunstancias aquí indican que los CDC emitieron la orden en un intento de buena fe de prevenir la propagación interestatal de COVID-19, basándose en una interpretación de buena fe de su autoridad en virtud de la PHSA. Esto basta para concluir que los CDC emitieron la orden dentro del ámbito normal de sus funciones a efectos de la demanda sobre expropiaciones”, escribió la jueza de circuito Sharon Prost para la mayoría del panel de la corte de circuito que examinó el recurso. Los funcionarios tampoco contravinieron ninguna prohibición explícita del Congreso al emitir la orden, dijo también la mayoría, señalando que los miembros nunca se solicitaron revocar la moratoria y de hecho aprobaron ampliarla un mes. “Justo antes de que la orden expirara por sus propios términos, el Congreso intervino y la prorrogó. Posteriormente, los CDC (ahora bajo una administración diferente) la prorrogaron varias veces más”, dijo Prost. “En todo momento, el gobierno defendió con vehemencia la legalidad de la orden frente a las impugnaciones. En conjunto, estos actos demuestran que la orden es un esfuerzo gubernamental sostenido y exhaustivo que lleva el sello distintivo de la acción gubernamental oficial. En estas circunstancias, existe realmente ‘un poco de reticencia natural a encontrar falta de autoridad’” por parte de los CDC. A Prost se unió la juez de circuito Kara F. Stoll. Los CDC, el Departamento de Justicia de EE.UU., que representa a los organismos gubernamentales en los litigios, y un abogado de los propietarios no devolvieron las solicitudes de comentarios. La Corte Suprema de EE.UU., en un caso separado, dictaminó anteriormente que los CDC no tenían autoridad para decretar la pausa de los desalojos. “Una cosa sería que el Congreso hubiera autorizado específicamente las medidas adoptadas por los CDC. Pero no ha sido así”, [dijo](https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/supreme-court-blocks-cdcs-eviction-moratorium-3967577) el tribunal en un dictamen sin firma. La mayoría del tribunal de apelaciones tomó nota de ese dictamen, pero dijo que no entraba en conflicto con su sentencia. “La cuestión de la autoridad legal es distinta de la cuestión de la autoridad a efectos de la demanda de expropiación. Sólo la primera estaba implicada” en el caso en el que falló la Corte Suprema, escribió Prost, añadiendo después que “no estamos dispuestos a asumir que la Corte Suprema, al evaluar el fondo de la cuestión de la autoridad estatutaria de la PHSA, también decidió implícitamente (o incluso sugirió) que la orden no estaba autorizada en el sentido de expropiación”. El Juez del Circuito de EE.UU. Timothy B. Dyk [dijo](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25035640-dissent-in-cdc-eviction-case) en un voto particular que la decisión de la mayoría sí entraba en conflicto con la decisión de la Corte Suprema. “En resumen, la decisión de la Corte Suprema sostuvo específicamente que la [moratoria de desalojos](https://es.theepochtimes.com/focus/moratoria-de-desalojos) estaba fuera del ámbito normal de las funciones de la agencia o de cualquier interpretación razonable de sus poderes”, escribió, y añadió que “no puede haber una demanda de expropiación por tales actos no autorizados de un funcionario del gobierno”. Únase a nuestro canal de Telegram para recibir las últimas noticias al instante [haciendo click aquí](https://t.me/EpochTimesEs) Cómo puede usted ayudarnos a seguir informando ¿Por qué necesitamos su ayuda para financiar nuestra cobertura informativa en Estados Unidos y en todo el mundo? Porque somos una organización de noticias independiente, libre de la influencia de cualquier gobierno, corporación o partido político. Desde el día que empezamos, hemos enfrentado presiones para silenciarnos, sobre todo del Partido Comunista Chino. Pero no nos doblegaremos. Dependemos de su generosa contribución para seguir ejerciendo un periodismo tradicional. Juntos, podemos seguir difundiendo la verdad.

author: Steve Wright
title: The Duskbloods is a FromSoftware Switch 2 exclusive coming 2026
text:
Get hype!
The Duskbloods was announced last night during the Nintendo Direct, a FromSoftware Switch 2 exclusive title that’s expected in 2026.
Beyond the trailer — which also confirms the game is multiplayer — not much else about the title was shared, though Nintendo and FromSoftware will detail more about the game from 6 April here in Australia.
For now, check out the trailer below.
Pretty neat, eh? What do you make of The Duskbloods at this stage?
We’ll have more on The Duskbloods as news becomes available.
This article may contain affiliate links, meaning we could earn a small commission if you click-through and make a purchase. Stevivor is an independent outlet and our journalism is in no way influenced by any advertiser or commercial initiative.

author: The Hindu Bureau
title: Heavy rain throws life out of gear in Tirunelveli and Tenkasi - The Hindu
text:
The Karuppanthurai bridge across Tamirabarani river in Tirunelveli Town has submerged due to continuous rain, as seen on Friday. | Photo Credit: A. SHAIKMOHIDEEN
Triggered by the well-marked low pressure area over Gulf of Mannar and another low pressure area over Lakshadweep-Maldives region coupled with upper air circulation, Tirunelveli and Tenkasi districts experienced heavy downpour from late Thursday, completely disrupting the normal life of people.
The heavy rainfall in the western ghats region has significantly increased the water flow in the Tamirabarani river. Among the notable records, Oothu received a maximum of 540 mm of rainfall by 6 a.m. on Friday. Despite only 800 cusecs of water being released from the dams in Tirunelveli district, the water flow into the urban areas soared to an alarming 65,000 cusecs by Friday afternoon.
In Tirunelveli city, key locations such as Tirunelveli Junction Bus Stand and neighbouring areas of Katchi Mandapam were heavily inundated. Karuppanthurai low-lying bridge which connects Melapalayam and Town was submerged under the heavy outflow of water in the Tamirabarani river.
Colin, owner of a photo lab at Town Junction bus stand, expressed his concerns over recurring floods. He said the flooding was majorly due to rampant encroachments along the canal’s waterways. He added that his equipment worth ₹75 lakh had been damaged in the flood.
As a precautionary measure, the government has requested people living in low-lying areas and riverbanks to relocate to safer places. Officials warned that if the heavy rainfall continues in western ghats, water inflow into the urban areas could surge to one lakh cusecs.
Tenkasi In Tenkasi, the floodwaters caused by torrential rain have submerged crops in the fields surrounding Thanjavurkulam. The downpour has resulted in flooding rivers such as Chittar, Hanuman river, Rama nadhhi, Gadana nadhi and Karuppanadhi making many villages inaccessible.
The breach of Thanjavurkulam banks caused flooding on Kollam-Tirumangalam highway leading to traffic congestion with vehicles stranded on both sides of the road.
Efforts to drain rainwater in Tirunelveli and Tenkasi districts are in full swing. Officials are taking steps to restore the roads which went under water due to the floods.
Later in the day, Municipal Administration Minister K.N. Nehru and Assembly Speaker M. Appavu inspected the flood-affected areas in Tirunelveli and urged officials to expedite the restoration work. Collector K.P. Karthikeyan was present during the inspection.
In Tenkasi, Revenue Minister K.K.S.S.R. Ramachandran inspected the flood-affected areas and met with 277 individuals from 77 families of ‘Narikuravar’ community who had been accommodated in the relief camp in Courtallam. Collector A.K. Kamal Kishore was present during the inspection.
Published - December 13, 2024 08:14 pm IST

author: Enoba
title: 5 best Milk Makeup lip products to try in 2025 - NewsBreak
text:
By Enoba ,
54 minutes ago
Milk Makeup has been around for a while, and beauty enthusiasts love the brand for its vegan and easy-to-use products. Their lip products are TikTok famous and extolled for their colorful and hydrating qualities.
The Cooling Water Jelly Tint is a ninth-time award winner and has received praise for its innovative beauty formula. Studies, as indicated on the brand’s website, have shown that other milk Makeup products, like the Odyssey Lip Oil Gloss and the KUSH Hydrating Lip Oil, provide smooth and plump lips.
The brand’s lip products are made from ingredients rich in vitamins and promise healthy and moisturized lips. The list below explores some of the best lip products from the New York City-based cosmetic company.
Disclaimer: This article reflects the writer's opinion only and is ranked in no particular order.
Electric Glossy Lip Plumper, The Odyssey lip oil gloss, and 3 other lip products from Milk Makeup to explore in 2025 1) Electric Glossy Lip Plumper Electric Glossy Lip Plumper (Image via Milk Makeup) The Electric Glossy Lip Plumper has received glowing reviews from beauty influencers and experts. The bestselling product promises fuller, smoother, and plumper lips after first and continuous use.
The lip product comes with a five-star rating on the brand’s website and features vegan ingredients. The glossy lip plumper has Sichuan pepper as an ingredient, which gives the appearance of smoother lips.
The Vegan collagen serves as a moisturizer for the lips. Volulip, another constituent, increases lip volume, while Jojoba oil is an antioxidant. Shop this bestseller for $25 on the brand’s website.
2) The Odyssey Lip Oil gloss The Odyssey Lip Oil gloss (Image via Milk Makeup) The Odyssey Lip Oil Gloss is a bestseller, and for good reason. Consumers praise the gloss for its long-lasting, hydrating, and non-sticky features. This lip oil gloss boasts a five-star review and features natural, cruelty-free, and, clean products.
The Jojoba oil constituent is rich in antioxidants and acts, alongside the Goji berry extract, which promotes skin elasticity. The cloudberry seed oil boasts high levels of vitamins C and E for nourishing and moisturizing the lips. The Odyssey Lip Oil Gloss comes with a price tag of $26 on the brand’s website.
3) KUSH Sheer Hydrating Lip Oil KUSH Sheer Hydrating Lip Oil (Image via Milk Makeup) This lip product from Milk Makeup boasts a five-star review and effective clinical results from a consumer perception study of over 31 users. The brand describes the KUSH Sheer Hydrating lip oil as a product that promises hydration and fuller-looking lips.
The 92% naturally made lip product features Hemp seed oil, which conditions and hydrates the lips. The Sunflower and coconut oil combo works to soothe and moisten. The Camellia Japonica seed oil constituent helps restore chapped lips. Shop the KUSH Sheer Hydrating lip oil for $26 on the brand’s website.
4) Lip + Cheek cream blush + lip color Lip + Cheek cream blush + lip color (Image via Milk Makeup) The versatile lip + cheek from Milk Makeup is a color palette for the lips and a non-comedogenic blush stick for the cheeks. According to the brand description, the product blends easily with makeup and offers a pop of color.
The Lip + Cheek lip color and blush come in both shades of cream and shimmer. For use as lipstick, twist off the protective disk from the stick and apply directly on the lips. The Lip + Cheek stems from mango butter, Avocado, and Apricot oil. Shop the 2-in-1 product for $24 on the brand’s website.
5) Cooling Water Jelly Tint Cooling Water Jelly Tint (Image via Milk Makeup) The Cooling Water Jelly Tint was named the Makeup Product of the Year by WWD and Beauty Inc. The jelly-like lip product acts as a jelly blush and lip stain and comes in six shades.
The brand describes this product as a hydrating mix that provides a sheer and long-lasting color on the lips and face. It is made from Vegan collagen, Aloe Vera, and seawater. Shop this bestselling lip product for $24 on the brand’s website.

author: Mirage News
title: Celebrating 50 Years of Service in Defence Department | Mirage News
text: For Warrant Officer Class Two (WO2) William 'Bob' Parsons, a journey that began fresh out of high school on June 13, 1973, is about to conclude with a remarkable half-century of service to the Australian Army. WO2 Parsons' commitment to Defence was recognised on November 19 with a third Federation Star, along with a seventh clasp on his Defence Long Service Medal. Commander 2nd (Australian) Division Major General David Thomae presented the awards in a ceremony that coincided with the end of Exercise Rhoden Strike. WO2 Parsons proudly shared his memories with the assembled friends and family members. "I passed my Centurion drivers' course, allowing me to drive 52 tons of main battle tank before I was allowed to apply for a civilian learner's permit to drive my dad's Morris 1000 on Victorian roads," he said. "I think that's a bit of an achievement." The presence of WO2 Parsons' family at the ceremony - including his wife Kerry, who he thanked for the 'team effort', and his son, also WO2 Robert Parsons, who serves in the Royal Australian Armoured Corps, underscored the familial ties that have supported his journey. Currently serving as a training development officer for Melbourne University Regiment at Anglesea Barracks in Hobart, WO2 Parsons continues to impart the lessons he has learned from his extensive career, highlighting the importance of self-discipline, taking care of soldiers, and the crucial role played by junior non-commissioned officers in Army's chain of command. Throughout his career, WO2 Parsons has gained many qualifications across armoured vehicles and has completed numerous overseas training stints. When asked for advice from young soldiers, he emphasises the value of persistence. "Stick with it. You'll have a lot of opportunities and experiences the Army offers you, as well as the camaraderie you'll experience along the way," he said. To those considering a career in Defence, WO2 Parsons said: "Give it a go ... the opportunities provided to you will be lifelong experiences that you'll be able to look back on". Upon retirement, he plans to continue travelling with Kerry, work on his golf handicap and spend more time with family. He also expressed a keen interest in giving back to the Hobart community, seeking local volunteer opportunities where he can continue to make a positive impact. [here](https://www.miragenews.com/celebrating-50-years-of-service-in-defence-1150241/).
